1495780709428043783.text: Presidents’ Day is an opportunity now to reflect on the unparalleled legacy and blessings we have been afforded in this exceptional country of ours--and to pass that along to our children and grandchildren. As Washington admonished in his Farewell Address:

1495780493073207302.text: Today is also the day that Washington's famous Farewell Address is read in its entirety on the floor of the U.S. Senate--which is a tradition that began on February 22, 1862, during the darkest days of the Civil War, as an effort to remind America of our unity and greatness.

1495780190450069509.text: Since we included the observance of Abraham Lincoln’s birthday (February 12) at that time, the joint celebration became known as “Presidents’ Day.”

1495779952620449792.text: The stated purpose of the statute creating more 3-day weekends was to “bring substantial benefits to both the spiritual and economic life of the Nation.”

1495779780393934858.text: In 1968, Congress passed the Monday Holiday Law to “provide uniform annual observances of certain legal public holidays on Mondays.”

1495779478878007299.text: Our nation began celebrating George Washington’s birthday on February 22, 1800, just two months after his death in December 1799. The tradition was observed annually until 1879, when Congress officially declared it a federal holiday.

1495779250162573312.text: A little background on this uniquely American holiday: https://t.co/jjTjYUIzbx
